    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the line \\( y\u003dx \\) around the x-axis, where \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 4 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is a cone with radius 4 and height of 4. Since the volume of a cone is given by the formula \\( V\u003d{\\frac {1}{3}}\\pi r^{2}h \\) , we should get a volume of \\( {\\frac {64\\pi }{3}} \\) . Our axis of revolution is the x-axis so our radius function is a function of x. Moreover, it is \\( r(x)\u003dx \\) since the distance from our axis of revolution to the function is always x. Thus, the volume is given by \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{4}}x^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\left[{\\frac {1}{3}}x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{4}}\u003d{\\frac {64\\pi }{3}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "f3c30177-30bc-4c5d-a35b-8b3322c58b68",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and \\( y\u003d4x-x^{2} \\) around the x-axis. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To do this problem, we first need to figure out what the region looks like. The intersection of the two graphs comes when \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}\u003d4x-x^{2}\\Rightarrow 2x^{2}-4x\u003d0\\Rightarrow 2x(x-2)\u003d0\\Rightarrow x\u003d0,2 \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe function \\( y\u003d4x-x^{2} \\) is the outermost function since we are revolving about the x-axis. Thus, we can find the volume by finding the volume of the solid generated by revolving \\( 4x-x^{2} \\) about the x-axis and subtracting the volume of the solid generated by revolving \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) about the x-axis. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(4x-x^{2})^{2}\\,dx-\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(x^{2})^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(-8x^{3}+16x^{2})\\,dx \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\pi \\left[-2x^{4}+{\\frac {16}{3}}x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{2}}\u003d\\pi \\left[-32+{\\frac {128}{3}}\\right]\u003d{\\frac {32\\pi }{3}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) around the x-axis. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, we need to find the intersection points of the two graphs. These are easy to find with these particular points. The intersections come at \\( x\u003d0,1 \\) . Since \\( x^{2} \\) is greater than \\( x^{3} \\) between 0 and 1, and because we are revolving this region about the x-axis, our outer function is \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) . So, we will find the volume of the solid of revolution using \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and subtract from this the volume of the solid of revolution using \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) . That is, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}\\left[(x^{2})^{2}-(x^{3})^{2}\\right]\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}(x^{4}-x^{6})\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\left[{\\frac {1}{5}}x^{5}-{\\frac {1}{7}}x^{7}\\right]_{{0}}^{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {2\\pi }{35}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) around the y-axis. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e By inspection, we can see that these two curves intersect at \\( x\u003d0,1 \\) . Also, in revolving this region about the y-axis, the function \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) is the outside function. All we need to do the integral is to change our functions into functions of y, instead of x. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}\\left[(y^{{{\\frac {1}{3}}}})^{2}-(y^{{{\\frac {1}{2}}}})^{2}\\right]\\,dy\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}\\left[y^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}}}-y\\right]\\,dy\u003d\\pi \\left[{\\frac {3}{5}}y^{{{\\frac {5}{3}}}}-{\\frac {1}{2}}y^{2}\\right]_{{0}}^{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi }{10}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003d{\\sqrt {x}} \\) , the x-axis and the line \\( x\u003d4 \\) around the x-axis.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is pretty straightforward. We will integrate x on the interval [0,4]. There is only one function so we do not need to subtract out any hole in the middle. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{4}}({\\sqrt {x}})^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\left[{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\right]_{{0}}^{{4}}\u003d8\\pi \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume, on the interval \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 3 \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is a square with side length \\( x^{2}-9x \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, think about finding the area under a curve. We integrate the function to do this but essentially what we are doing is adding up an infinite amount of infinitely skinny lines and these lines (1-D objects) add up to give us the area. The function we integrate gives us the length of the line. It is a generalization of the formula A\u003dl\\times h for a rectangle. We get the infinitely many heights and we add them up over the length, the difference being that they vary. This problem is very similar though it might seem very different. Here, we are adding up an infinite amount of infinitely thin squares (2-D objects) and we will end up with the volume of the object. The function we integrate will give us the area, which we then add up to get a volume. Thus, the formula for finding a volume by cross-sectional areas is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{a}}^{{b}}A(x)\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e where we are finding the volume on the interval \\( [a,b] \\) and where A(x) gives a formula for the area of a general cross-section. Here, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e because the area of a square is equal to the square of its side length. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{4}-18x^{3}+81x^{2})\\,dx\u003d\\left[{\\frac {1}{5}}x^{5}-{\\frac {9}{2}}x^{4}+27x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{3}}\u003d{\\frac {4131}{10}}\u003d413.1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, the volume of this shape, whose cross-section is always a square with varying side length, is 413.1 cubic units. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "8c84d21c-e925-4cc9-83c8-630748511ffc",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",
      "createdAt": 1434556152979,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 1,
      "title": "Calculus Practice",
      "body": "Find the volume, on the interval \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 3 \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is a square with side length \\( x^{2}-9x \\) .",
      "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Volume,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration,auto-uploaded",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume, on the interval \\( 0\\leq x\\leq \\pi \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is an equilateral triangle with side length \\( \\sin {\\frac {x}{2}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e In an equilateral triangle, taking one side as the base, the height is the length of the perpendicular bisector to that side. If \\( y \\) is the side length in an equilateral triangle, the length of a perpendicular bisector is given by \\( {\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{2}}y \\) . So the area of a given equilateral triangle in this problem is given by \\( {\\frac {1}{2}}{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{2}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac {x}{2}}\\right) \\) . To find the volume, we integrate the area over the interval. Thus \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{4}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac {x}{2}}\\right)\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{4}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac {1-\\cos x}{2}}dx\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{8}}{\\bigg [}x-\\sin x{\\bigg ]}_{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{8}}[2\\pi ]\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}\\pi }{4}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the volume of this shape is \\( {\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}\\pi }{4}} \\) units. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "86e672f9-3f2d-4e25-a275-8914ee8bab5d",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",
      "createdAt": 1434556152993,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,

      "title": "Calculus Practice",
      "body": "Find the volume, on the interval \\( 0\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;2\\pi \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is an equilateral triangle with side length \\( \\sin {\\frac {x}{2}} \\) .",
      "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Volume,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration,auto-uploaded",
      "url": "/practice-problem/86e672f9-3f2d-4e25-a275-8914ee8bab5d",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of a cylinder with radius 3 and height 10. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, we are finding the volume of an object with circles for cross-sections. It is quite simple since, in a cylinder, the circles are all the same size. So, the cross-sectional area at any point is just \\( A\u003d\\pi (3)^{2} \\) . Since the area does not depend on x, it does not matter which interval we integrate over so long as it has a length of 10. So the volume is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{10}}9\\pi \\,dx\u003d9\\pi x{\\big |}_{{0}}^{{10}}\u003d90\\pi \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the volume is \\( 90\\pi \\) cubic units. This is the same answer we would get if we used the formula for the volume of a cylinder, \\( V\u003d\\pi r^{2}h \\) . This example shows that you can get the volumes of already known shapes but you can also get volumes for shapes with varying cross-sectional areas for which there is on specific formula. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "9fc15502-df93-4232-b272-aa38705014b2",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",
      "createdAt": 1434556153009,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 1,
      "title": "Calculus Practice",
      "body": "Find the volume of a cylinder with radius 3 and height 10.",

      "url": "/practice-problem/9fc15502-df93-4232-b272-aa38705014b2",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eCalculate the arc length of the curve \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) from \\( x\u003d0 \\) to \\( x\u003d4 \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe calculate using the general formula for arc length: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( L\u003d\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt {1+\\left({\\frac {dy}{dx}}\\right)^{2}}}\\,dx\u003d\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt {1+(2x)^{2}}}\\,dx \\) . We need to use a trig substitution on this\u0026nbsp;; namely, let \\( 2x\u003d\\tan \\theta \\) , so \\( 2\\,dx\u003d\\sec ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta \\) . Calculate the antiderivative first: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx\u003d\\int {\\sqrt {1+\\tan ^{2}\\theta }}\\cdot {\\frac {1}{2}}\\sec ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta \u003d\\int {\\frac {1}{2}}\\sec ^{3}\\theta \\,d\\theta \u003d{\\frac {1}{4}}\\left(\\tan \\theta \\,\\sec \\theta +\\ln |\\tan \\theta +\\sec \\theta |\\right) \\) . We substitute for \\( x \\) to get \\( \\int {\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{4}}\\left(2x{\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}+\\ln |2x+{\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}|\\right)+C \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen \\( L\u003d\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx\u003d\\left.{\\frac {1}{4}}\\left(2x{\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}+\\ln |2x+{\\sqrt {1+4x^{2}}}|\\right)\\right|_{{x\u003d0}}^{4}\u003d{\\frac {1}{4}}\\left(8{\\sqrt {65}}+\\ln(8+{\\sqrt {65}})\\right) \\) . \u003c/p\u003e",

      "body": "Calculate the arc length of the curve \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) from \\( x\u003d0 \\) to \\( x\u003d4 \\) .",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDetermine the arc length of the curve given by x \u003d t cos t , y \u003d t sin t from t\u003d0 \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe have a parametrization of the curve as \\( x\u003dt\\cos t,\\,y\u003dt\\sin t \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d\\cos t-t\\sin t,\\,{\\dot {y}}\u003d\\sin t+t\\cos t \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( ({\\dot {x}})^{2}+({\\dot {y}})^{2}\u003d(\\cos t-t\\sin t)^{2}+(\\sin t+t\\cos t)^{2}\u003d(\\cos ^{2}t-2t\\cos t\\sin t+t^{2}\\sin ^{2}t)+(\\sin ^{2}t+2t\\sin t\\cos t+t^{2}\\cos ^{2}t) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \u003d\\cos ^{2}t+\\sin ^{2}t+t^{2}\\sin ^{2}t+t^{2}\\cos ^{2}t\u003d1+t^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn order to integrate we now need a substitution: Let \\( t\u003d\\cosh u\\Rightarrow dt\u003d\\sinh u\\,du,{\\sqrt {1+t^{2}}}\u003d\\sinh u \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Hence \\( L\u003d\\int _{{\\operatorname {arcosh}0}}^{{\\operatorname {arcosh}u}}\\sinh ^{2}u\\,du\u003d\\left[{\\frac {\\sinh 2u-2u}{4}}\\right]_{{\\operatorname {arcosh}0}}^{{\\operatorname {arcosh}u}}\u003d\\left[{\\frac {2t{\\sqrt {1+t^{2}}}-2\\operatorname {arcosh}\\,t}{4}}\\right]_{0}^{t}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}t{\\sqrt {1+t^{2}}}-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\operatorname {arcosh}\\,t \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "uuid": "4dc4e3c7-f864-489e-854b-07e37bc29636",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437419361937,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Question On Monotone (increasing And Decreasing) Sequences",

      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Convergence Of Sequences Question",
      "body": " Let  \\begin{align*} a_1 \u0026\u003d \\sqrt2\\\\          a_2 \u0026\u003d \\sqrt{2+\\sqrt2}\\\\          a_3 \u0026\u003d \\sqrt{2+\\sqrt{2+\\sqrt2}}\\\\              \u0026  \\vdots  \\end{align*}\n  (a) Express  \\(a_{n+1}\\)  in terms of  \\(a_n\\) .\n  (b) Prove that  \\((a_n)\\)  has a limit, say  \\(r\\) .   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e Show first that  \\(\\sqrt2 \\le a_n \u003c 2\\)  for all \\(n\\) .\n  (c) Find  \\(r\\) .",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "sequences of real numbers, sequences ,monotone (increasing and decreasing) sequences ,bounded sequences ,convergence of sequences",

    {

      "creatorUserId": "",

      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Practice In Sequences Of Real Numbers",
